tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/strategy.message: what are the gaps there so we need a custom one?

1) free doesn't fail a playbook if there's a failure
2) free doesn't support run_once (i plan on addressing that here)
3) this sets us up to be able to implement failure allowance based on tripleo roles. e.g. max_failure_percentage based on tripleo role

So I tested, free does not stop playbook execution like the proposed tripleo_free. Meaning our deployment would continue to process rather than stopping after a failure occurs during a playbook being executed via free. 

Example: http://paste.openstack.org/show/793296/

In the example you see that for 'free', the "Run another playbook" executes on all the other hosts and so the overall playbook is not stopped after the first failure. We want it to not move on to the next playbook.


Now this is likely some code that we can contribute upstream however I'm uncertain if that would be wanted by the upstream ansible community. I find it odd that it didn't support that in the first place but who knows.

The second item which I had previously indicated that I wanted to fix is the run_once (similar issue). 

And the final item that will be addressed in a future revision is support for failures based on tripleo roles. 

The first two issues could likely be addressed in future versions of ansible, however unlikely to be backportable to version we want. While today 'free' could be used and it'll pass if everything is OK, it won't fail correctly.

Ansible is pushing for things in collections, so in general they are looking for folks to pick up and extend but not necessarily land in core. I personally feel that this is one of those improvements that should live in our world for now because it is closely tied to how we want our deployment framework to execute and I'm uncertain of the external overlap. I will be looking to propose these types of fixes to upstream ansible once we've vetted them but I'm uncertain of their desire for them.


It should also be noted that the 'default' callback has assumptions around the use of 'free' so it completely hoses the output if you switch to something named other than 'free' which is where my callback improvement patches are coming from.

have you checked to see what tasks no longer honor run_once because of this?

we use run_once a lot for performance reasons, and it accounted for reducing some of the biggest bottlenecks in the scale lab testing. These things wouldn't show up in CI.

tripleo_ssh_known_hosts and tripleo_hosts_entries are the two that come to mind, and I see in the tht patch that those wouldn't be affected since they will still use the linear strategy.

My goal is to make run_once work as all tasks have a UUID so we should be able to check that it was at least triggered once. The issue comes does into ensuring it actually completed.  We're likely to see more improvements by switching to free than using run_once because they don't run in lockstep anymore.  I don't think we use run_once in the deployment steps themselves but yes my goal is to actually make it work correctly. I think if a task is run_once and it fails it should fail the playbook if it fails.
And these are surprisingly useful when debugging. :)
No, -vvvv shows debug lines.  anything less than that -v, -vv, -vvv won't show these
There's a bug here where it won't stop because result gets overwritten on subsequent loops (if we don't fail outright)
Should we set this to True by default like 'host_pinned'? i.e run all tasks in a play for a host without interruption? You seem to have the code for it in L266.

I'm going to test if host_pinned = true is better than just free.  This code is similar to the ansible free in that the host_pinned strategy just inherits from the free one and switch this value to true.  In my original testing I had host_pinned = true but I did see some better results with host_pinned = false.
Why do all the name setting gymnastics? It doesn't seem like the redefined task name is used outside of send_callback?
Since python is pass-by-reference, task may be used elsewhere and this might cause problems. This is how it's handled in the upstream strategy

helm-chart-collator/README.md.message:
to elaborate on my comments about reflecting all chart source info into the produced versions, at first my thought was to include this info in a human readable way, using semver prerelease / build metadata, however those only allow dot-separated alpha numerics, so URLs/paths/etc cannot (completely) be included in this way. So instead an alternative to still generate a unique version would be to just convert each chart source entry in the input into JSON and generate an alpha-numeric hash of this JSON, and include that into the produced semver pre-release / build metadata:

1.0.0+source.a8xf9cz

could optionally include whatever human readable fields that can easily be encoded in semver as well:

1.0.0+source.a8xf9cz.repo.stable
1.0.0+source.m5r4q23.repo.rook-release
1.2.3+source.q22tbf7.git.deps.openstackhelminfra

would also probably need to include the other chart source metadata into the produced helm repo's index.yaml entries, so that one can have a human readable way to determine the full chart source associated with each version, not sure what chartmuseum supports for that.
nit: not a big deal, but charts under "helm_repos" could also be considered "packaged charts" as well. Maybe something like "urls" or "tars" would be more informative.

nit: looks like this field is unused in the code right now? That would make sense since presumably helm pulls the name from the download file name which is determined from the URL itself, in which case the name field would be redundant.

as it stands we are not including the resolved commit SHA for these floating tags in the generated semver version, so two different commits could lead to the same generated version. so I think we should do one of:

1. Add resolved commit SHA to generated semver version
2. Disallow floating tags in the input i.e. require commit SHAs.

Option 2. seems ideal since it avoids accidental updates to new commits when re-generating the image. It looks like the `refspec` may be needed to be added as an option in this case:

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/git_module.html#parameter-version
Should be a blank line before list.

helm-chart-collator/playbooks/roles/inst.message: conflicts may not be super likely here, but it would probably be good to move this to some sub-directory to prevent them.
done. I've switched to using the /tmp directory. Pretty sure that guarantees no conflicts

I think the most common use case would be auto-generating the chart version based on chart['version'] / chart['refspec'] /chart['path'] / chart['dependencies'][...]. The Helm Operator caches chart versions coming from helm repos, so if the collated helm repo contains updated charts, but the versions are not updated, it would not download the updates, unless the cache is cleared by e.g. restarting the operator. Also the version numbers become ambiguous as to whether they are referring to the old or new configs.

ok I understand now. The default version currently *is* based on the chart source. Passing a value for `chart.version` would override.

Perhaps we should remove the ability to override? That would remove the need to manually update chart.version. Thoughts?
Unless I'm misunderstanding, this sounds like an issue with the operator as opposed to the collator?

so I'm talking about the *output* versions reflecting the entire input source info, including an unspecified version leading to a new version being downloaded from an upstream repo etc.

elaborated in a separate comment.
alright, I think I got it this time

I think caching is a useful feature, the operator could presumably be updated to support disabling caching, but generally the helm chart versions are not meant to change over time (like floating tags do), rather a new a version should be published when there are changes, that way version references uniquely identify the desired helm chart content. So that is why I was suggesting generating a unique version based on the chart source, at least as the default, rather than relying on the user always having to update the chart_version when updating the chart source.

This is completely untested, but this gives the idea of what I was thinking:

sha=$(echo -n '{{ chart | to_json }}' | sha256sum)
version=$(helm show chart <chart path> | yq .version)
gen_version="${version}+source.${sha}"

and the same for helm repo sourced charts. for git may want to also add the resolved commit SHA, so that git floating tags e.g. `master` don't lead to the same generated version for different commits.

could optionally add some human readable tag that the user can specify e.g. chart['version_id']
Is there a reason not to go ahead and include `--version={{ chart["version"] }}`?

may be useful to use e.g. /charts/helm_repo here and /charts/git for git charts to make it more human readable as to where charts were sourced from when building the image. This way for e.g. code reviews when updating a helm chart version in a HelmRelease, one doesn't have to look into the collator build input to determine this.

that makes sense. in any case probably better would be to use semver build metadata in the generated version e.g. 1.0.0-git+refspec.<refspec> or 1.0.0-helm_repo+upstream.<upstream helm repo url>. The primary version e.g. 1.0.0 could be extracted from the Chart.yaml of the source chart, at least for git, for helm repo sourced charts perhaps can just use the same version being pulled from the upstream helm repo i.e. `chart['version']`.
I'm not following this - to serve the charts, chartmuseum needs them all to be in the same directory

i think ideally chart['version'] would be required to avoid scenarios where someone is referencing a chart version from collator image A, and then collator image B accidentally replaces that chart version with a new one, due to a new latest chart version in the upstream helm repo.

I don't see any sort of documentation, whether a comment in the Dockerfile or a README that would help an end-user understand to provide a space-delimited list of chart names.  Is it a list of chartNames? chartName:version? I cannot recall if there is only ever one version in the stable repo at a given time for each chart.  What if multiple versions are available?

specs/approved/owner-aware-nodes.rst.message: In the case of ...
Done

My feeling is that assigning nodes to projects won't be the common case. Is there not a way that we could solve this problem without requiring nodes to be assigned to projects?

It seems that something like a 'sudo' for keystone would be useful, or perhaps something akin to keystone trusts where the user is granted a superset of privileges rather than a subset.

@vdrok: Right, I don't think 'supertrusts' exist currently - perhaps I went off on a tangent there, although they could be useful.

Perhaps if we break apart the separate things we want from this a solution will present itself? How would you solve each of these problems (admin-less deployment, L32 and node pooling, L37) independently? I think that the solution for admin-less deployment would not likely involve projects, so why don't we consider that separately, then consider how to segregate nodes into separate pools of resources?

The project is what we'll most likely have present in the context, so this was my first thought.

As for making it a kind of sudo with trusts, sounds like an interesting idea. Tho when used with nova, I think this will complicate things. Firstly, we'd need to pass the context the boot request came in from nova to ironic. Secondly, it seems like apart from that it's mostly the same, we'd store trust id instead of project id. The upside of trust seems to be that it can be revoked easily, tho doing node-update remove owner should be as easy as that for an admin :)

Also I'm no keystone expert, but trusts seem to me like also delegating a subset of possible actions to the trustee.

We actually already do this for some things, like Neutron. We "elevate" the client connection to use an administrator role when needed:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L855-L857

The same could be done for Ironic.

I think this is a very important use case for ironic. I was chatting to someone on IRC who had a very similar requirement.

That said, I'm a little concerned about making projects the dimension of separation. Jay Pipes touched earlier on the distinction between ownership and permissions. There's also the question of scheduling. I may want to be able to allow users to target an arbitrary subset of nodes for scheduling, without necessarily adding any restrictions on which users can do that.

I think ironic is in need of a more generic pooling system, with the flexibility of nova's aggregates (what a shame it doesn't 'just work' today).

Some use cases that are not mine but feel like they shouldn't be designed out:

* A node assigned to a project, restricts use to only users in that project.
* A node assigned to multiple projects, restricts use to only users in those projects (a la glance membership).
* Two pools representing disjoint sets of nodes, which may be scheduled against.
* Two pools representing intersecting sets of nodes, which may be scheduled against (i.e. some nodes are in multiple pools).

I'm not suggesting that this spec needs to solve the general problem, only that I'd like to see the general problem considered before deciding how this fits into the picture. 

Perhaps also less emphasis on this being *the* solution for pooling nodes.

I think that a single baremetal_deployer role for all nodes is currently sufficient.

On the scheduling side, I wasn't really meaning removing nodes permanently from the schedulable pool, more about having abstractions for building pools/groups that could be scheduled against.

Having a list of owners (like glance image members) feels more flexible than a single owner. I'm still not sure it covers all use cases though - we might want to limit scheduling to a subset of the nodes owned by a project. Again, that doesn't mean I don't like the idea of node ownership, I just we should be clear that it solves a particular use case and is not *the* way to partition nodes.

Right, but still I think ownership and permissions are isolated here. baremetal_deployer role says what you can do with a node, owner field says who can do that. Do you think it's make more sense to store both owner id and role name in the node? You can redefine baremetal_deployer to be whatever you want, but yes, it will be the same for all nodes.

As for just restricting a subset of nodes for scheduling without any restrictions to what you can do with them, you can already do that, just put them in maintenance :) or do you mean something more elaborate? Like telling nova compute to not report nodes having some field set? I'm not sure it fits the current proposal, but if you could add more detail here, I'll think about how to fit it here.

As for pooling solution, we can actually do all the things you propose with the project_id filtering, if we make the owner field to be a list of project ids, which will mean multiple traits will be assigned to some resource providers.

This still seems useful in the case where nodes have no owner. Users across all projects could be assigned the baremetal_deployer role allowing them to deploy a node with no owner or owned by their project.

I guess you potentially lose backwards compatibility by requiring users to have the baremetal_deployer role, which is an issue. I am a bit concerned about creating two separate sets of logic here though, depending on whether a user happens to have the baremetal_deployer role or not. It would be nice if we could fix the common case somehow (which remains admin-requiring in this spec, so nova still needs admin unless *all* nodes are owned), and work project ownership into that?
hrm, my intent was actually to make nodes with no owner to be admin only, do you think it's better to do the way you propose here?
Perhaps worth stating early on that null is possible and represents current behaviour? That question occurred to me and I found myself skipping ahead to find the answer.
++ will do
Needs updating for storage?
Done
I think the chassis concept is a bit overused currently, better not complicate it ;-)
yeah absolutely agree
What happens when some nodes are owned and some are not? Can a user in a project with dedicated nodes also provision nodes with no owner?
Ok, but would the nova ironic driver see that the node is not owned and use admin, even for users with the baremetal_deployer role?
nope, current behaviour means nodes being admin-only

It seems a shame that this is all or nothing. I could imagine a case where there is a large shared pool of nodes and several smaller pools dedicated to specific projects.

In that case, would it be possible to check whether the user has the baremetal_deployer role? If so, the shared nodes could be added to a shared node project, and the 'admin' user could just be another user with a baremetal_deployer role in the shared nodes project.

It does seem like things will get fiddly if ownership and non-ownership is mixed.

Yes, I guess that's true.

Just a thought here, if we are requiring users to have the baremetal_deployer role in order to deploy, then those users will have access to those ironic API calls (assuming they can reach it), without needing to use nova.

Yeah, but the problem is, what is considered a baremetal_deployer is defined in the ironic policy, and it can be changed if needed by the operator, so not sure how we could achieve this. We could just do requests to ironic to check who is an owner of a particular node, but it seems like it is not a good way and will slow down scheduling.
This upgrade doesn't sound very rollable...
Yeah :( tho even right now we have to restrict some actions during the upgrade to avoid weird situations. This is the case when it has to be done.

This is an interesting use of traits. I guess it kind of makes sense: you're trying to say indicate two things:

* this baremetal has the trait of being owned by "foouser"

So problem can now be avoided using the service user, as described here:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ocata/implemented/use-service-tokens.html

Basically Nova sends keystone middleware on downstream service two tokens, a Nova service token, along with the user's token. The middleware will ignore the expiry of the user token for a configurable number of hours to stop token expiry issues.

... having said all that, I think it might make the next bits easier to implement. It also enables the option of reserving some things for only Nova to assign, if you so wish.

A couple points...

1) Unfortunately, the above is redefining the term "tenant" to mean something that the term tenant (really, "project" now..) means in the rest of OpenStack services. In the rest of OpenStack services, a tenant (project) is a set of end-users of the cloud. Generally, we don't refer to administrative users -- those users that have the ability to see the resources of the underlying infrastructure -- as a "tenant". What you're referring to as a "tenant" here is really just an admin user that only has the ability to see a certain subset of the infrastructure's resources.

2) You are coupling the concepts of "ownership" with "permissions". The two concepts are very different, and generally in OpenStack, we use the *role* in Keystone to determine access rights/permissions and we use the *project* to describe ownership.

more below...

OK, yeah, this is all about allowing some specific actions with a node to non-admins. I'm not sure how to name this to avoid confusion, maybe replace tenant to owner everywhere? Basically tenant=owner=project in this spec.

As for "What you're referring to as a "tenant" here is really just an admin user that only has the ability to see a certain subset of the infrastructure's resources.", not sure I understand what you meant here, this user does not have to be an admin (and should not be). To list the resources of ironic, we already have a baremetal_observer role, which by default allows listing of all the resources in ironic. baremetal_deployer is separate.

Nova already provides the multi-tenancy, multi-user API on top of Ironic. We already have a construct for dealing with dividing up a set of infrastructure resources into different groups: the aggregate. There is even already a way via the AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation scheduler filter to specific which tenants a group of hosts/nodes should be used for which tenants. Has Ironic considered using this existing functionality?

Yes, but I'm trying to make this possible for standalone ironic deployments as well, hence trying to come up with a solution so that ironic is a source of truth for all cases, to e.g. avoid duplicating the project_id both somewhere in ironic and nova, and setting it only in ironic.

I fail to see why any there should be any changes to the way that state transitions in Ironic. Whether a node belongs to a group of nodes that a tenant owns should not affect the lifecycle of a baremetal Ironic node. What am I missing here?

It does not affect the state machine at all (well, in a sense of making changes to it). If say cleaning fails, the node will go into clean fail state, and moved to maintenance. Then, the admin will have to come in, investigate, and move the node to some other state if needed, or allocate another node for that tenant.

The things that the "usual deployer" should be able to do are deploy/redeploy/tear down with automated cleaning. The check to see if a specific user can set the target provision state to some specific value is checked by policy on the api level, not on the state machine level.

The cleaning failure is one example when the recovery should be an admin-only action. For example, the firmware write failed on some of the controllers. If a user will just move the node from maintenance and retries the cleaning, they can brick some controller, and the node will basically become broken. It should be investigated by an admin. The deployment failure on the other hand is pretty safe, eg if some incorrect image was provided, we can allow to redeploy.
i believe this means password. But does anything else apart from password is assumed here in sensitive information?
Here I mean whatever we hide with the helper functions in the API. IIRC we also hide ssh key.

This is a significant change to the placement API and overall design. One thing we have insisted on is not to have any overt Nova-isms in placement, so that it can be used for all kinds of resources, not just virtualization. You seem to be proposing to add an Ironic-specific behavior to placement, and that is not going to work well, for the same reasons we avoid Nova-specific features.

Yup, and I understand your and Chris' logic, it does not look that good :) OTOH, it can be not something nova-specific, just some identifier?

When I was thinking about this, I found https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filters/aggregate_multitenancy_isolation.py, hence this proposal.

What would you think be a better place to store such kind of information, if you think it's worth it at all? Maybe creating traits on the fly according to the owner column and associating them with the resource provider? Basically, all of this is needed just so that scheduler does not pick up a node of another "owner" (both if a node has an owner that does not correspond what's in the context, or does not have owner, as it means it is admin-only).

How bad/slow would it be to, instead of storing tenant information with the resource providers, enter a retry loop until a valid baremetal node has been landed upon? Since a single compute-node can know about multiple ironic nodes, that loop could potentially happen within the compute-node itself, without having to bump to the scheduler doing the retry (which, since there are some plans to limit/stop retries at the scheduler layer would be important).

I'm not saying this is a good idea, just throwing it out there to stimulate thinking about alternate strategies. If checking to see if the destination is "okay" is not a big problem, it might be a useful tool.
Hmm, but if say one tenant owns 2 nodes and another one owns 998, it will be a pretty high number of retries before succeeding?

As a general rule, I think we need to think hard before we change the data model used in the placement service. Conceptually a resource provider hasn't been something that has an owner. Instead it is a thing which provides some inventory against which allocations (which very soon _will_ have an owner) can be made.

Allocations having an owner makes conceptual sense.

baremetal nodes confuse the model because each single node is a resource provider with inventory that can be allocated against only once.

I have more to say about this, but I'm being called away, so will finish up later.

So, I was suggesting a higher-level "max_concurrent_snapshots" config, where we don't even start the snapshot operation until we have one of the available slots. By using this config, and doing the semaphore acquire deep down in the glance code, we will pause the instance and then presumably wait for a long time until we get the semaphore. If we do it in the snapshot operation, we can keep running until we get a slot, pause, snapshot, resume.

Now, we maybe should *also* grab this one in the glance code so that we honor the intention of this config (i.e. any/all heavy disk ops), but this isn't what I was suggesting.

https://eventlet.net/doc/threading.html#eventlet.tpool.execute



eventlet.tpool.execute(meth, *args, **kwargs)

    Execute meth in a Python thread, blocking the current coroutine/ greenthread until the method completes.

    The primary use case for this is to wrap an object or module that is not amenable to monkeypatching or any of the other tricks that Eventlet uses to achieve cooperative yielding. With tpool, you can force such objects to cooperate with green threads by sticking them in native threads, at the cost of some overhead.

The simplest thing to do with tpool is to execute() a function with it. The function will be run in a random thread in the pool, while the calling coroutine blocks on its completion:

so it will still be blocking in terms of the lifetime of this coroutine but it will not block the main tread as the current greenthread will yield until the snapshot is completed.


even though the total number of snapshots will be limited by the size of the thread pool i think we still need to add the new max_concurrent_shapshots config option and add a sepmephoen to limit the number of snapshots that happen at once. so ill keep my -1 untill other way in on that but the blocking/yeilding behavior is fine. there is no race here.

glance/async_/flows/_internal_plugins/co.message: Yikes, this is a bad assumption for sure.

I'm surprised that we don't check the image hash instead of just the existence (and now size) of the image. I haven't looked, but shouldn't we calculate the image hash as we're downloading it, store that in a sidecar file at the end and compare that to the expected hash? That would be much safer, but maybe it's not possible for some reason.

What I meant was, if when we're downloading to stage in the first place, we calculate the image as we're reading it, we could store the hash in a sidecar and then we'd know that a past stage operation had calculated the same hash as the image we're now being asked to push to the store. Something like:

 $staging_dir/the_image.img
 $staging_dir/the_image.img.SHA1  << has the hash inside

Calculating it as we're downloading it involves some extra CPU during the download, but doesn't require us to re-read the whole image here when we resume the upload to the store. It helps avoid propagating a failure or an attack on the image in the source store.

Anyway, I'm just surprised to see less hash checking in glance than I assumed from the outside was being done. This operation where we would trust prior residue in the staging dir is a liability, but obviously the immediate solution here is what you have.

As this check implies that the file is already in staging;
calculating hash will result in reading whole file again, so IMO size check will be enough.
I don't think you have a test for this case.

Given the issue that arose to result in this review being proposed, we may want to try/except the tmp path creation and fail with a more useful error message if there is a permissions problem?

The root cause of the problem is not that the remote user is wrong (although this patch fixes that if it happens to be the case), but that the tmp_path is owned by another user (likely root) with the permissions of 700 so the remote user is unable to create the tmp_path.

I think it'd be prudent to put a try/except here to notify the user of that issue.

That said, https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/a3c1ea886ffd2115ea2475d5342fc8d015790643/lib/ansible/plugins/action/__init__.py#L408-L411 kinda helps - maybe that could be improved instead?

I'm not sure what the right approach is here.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py.message: nit: can you replace "setting" with "controller" in the line above?
Sure
Nit: Can you remove the word "either" above?
Sure

Setting reboot this way above will only have a correct result if the last controller supports EHBA mode, and it is currently in EHBA mode.  If the last controller doesn't support EHBA mode, then this "if" clause will never be entered and reboot will never be set to True.  This will result in the pending jobs to switch to RAID mode never running.

reboot should be set to True for the last controller that needs to be switched to RAID mode.  Unfortunately, we can't know that when we're in the middle of processing the controller list, so it looks like we will need to calculate that outside of this "for" loop.

You are right Chris. Let say we have two controllers:
 1. Controller in EHBA mode
 2. Controller in RAID mode
Then at line-1028 reboot will only be True for last controller. which is wrong.
So considering the condition, i have change the implementation and it will only create configuration job for the realtime controllers and none of them are in ehba mode

I don't think this is quite right.  This "elif" clause handles the case where not all controllers support realtime and at least one of them needs to switched from EHBA mode to RAID mode.  By looping through the controllers that need to be switched, we will never create config jobs for those controllers that do not need to be switched from EHBA mode to RAID mode.  Instead, I think we should loop through all controllers above.
Note that the line that calculates reboot below will also not work unless the last controller in controllers also happens to need to be switch to RAID mode.  This will be fixed if we loop through controllers instead of any_ehba_controllers.

Right. This could break the feature when we have RAID controller in raid mode and BOSS controller. I have changed the `any_ehba_controllers` condition as it will have the any controllers but atleast one ehba controller will exist. So it will only create single reboot job for the (last)ehba controller.

I'm not quite sure if this is right.  Say the controller supports realtime mode and it needs to be switched to RAID mode.  In that case, the 1st call to _create_config_job will pass reboot=False, and the call to _create_config_job above will also pass reboot=False.  That said, we know that there is at least one controller that does not support realtime mode, so reboot will be passed as True at some point in the first call.  Is this one reboot sufficient, or should reboot be passed as True in the line above if the controller does not support realtime mode and it needs to be switched to RAID mode?
Yes one reboot is sufficient if we have more than one controller. and in this condition(any_ehba_controllers) it will not create configuration job based on realtime.

I don't think we need this new code.  This "else" clause handles the case where not all the controllers support realtime mode AND any_ehba_controllers==False, which means that none of the controllers need to be switched to RAID mode.
Yes you are right, this code block does not belong to this condition.Dont known why i added it here.Removed

return False

> This was requests in review of the supporting spec: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/723665/1/specs/victoria/simple-container-generation.rst@105
I think we can nail this down into a single regex.

given every application must be in its own directory, maybe this should just pull in an arbitrary yaml file when found?

    def find_image(self, name, path):
        """Find an image and load its config.

        This will traverse a directory structure looking for an image
        directory, when found all configs will be loaded lexically and
        returned a single Dictionary.

        :param name: Container name.
        :type name: String.
        :param path: Directory path to traverse.
        :type path: String.

        :returns: Dictionary
        """
        container_vars = dict()
        for root, dirs, files in os.walk(path):
            if os.path.basename(path) == name:
                for file_name in sorted(files):
                    if file_name.endswith(('yaml', 'yml')):
                        with open(os.path.join(root, file_name)) as f:
                            container_vars.update(yaml.safe_load(f.read()))
        else:
            return container_vars


This would allow us to have multiple arbitrary configs within a given directory which are sorted (01-config.yaml, 02-config.yaml, etc) and loaded one on top the other.
we probably want more logging in general (log.debug level) for the actions we do here.

If we make the find_image change, we can update the playbook execution like so to support the given options:

            container_vars = {"workdir": work_dir}
            container_vars.update(image_config)
            utils.run_ansible_playbook(
                playbook="cli-generate-containerfile.yaml",
                inventory="localhost,",
                workdir=work_dir,
                playbook_dir=constants.ANSIBLE_TRIPLEO_PLAYBOOKS,
                extra_vars_file=container_vars,
                verbosity=utils.playbook_verbosity(self=self),
            )

/COMMIT_MSG.message: thanks for catching this Brian

we've 2 checks[1][2] regarding the source_volume and snapshots in the API layer which can be easily modified to associate the appropriate volume type.

Could you expand on why ExtractVolumeRequestTask is the appropriate place for it? 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/v3/volumes.py#L333-L341
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/api.py#L272-L283

Well, other checks like this are being done in the ExtractVolumeRequestTask, so it would keep all the validation in one place.  The major reason, though, is that we need to have access to the image metadata if an imageRef has been passed in the API call, and that requires a call out to the Image service API.
I feel the DB changes are important part of this feature as to mandating untyped volumes in the code doesn't seem of much use if the database can contain nullable values for volume type.

What we really want is that the volume_type_id be populated at the correct time, which we can tell by the volume status.  So we could move this out of the DB and into the object code, which could check the status field and raise an exception if there's no volume type.  Or do something like put a boolean column for "must have volume type" that gets set True when a volume first goes active, and then the OVO could raise if that column is True but volume_type_id is null.

cinder/tests/unit/volume/flows/api/test_.message: Thanks a lot for test data description
we can use the variable here as well but this also works for me
we won't be facing these type of scenario in real volume create flows, do we still need it?

I think so.  The aim of this test is to define the behavior of the selection function, so that if it gets refactored and something here breaks, we'll know to look more closely.  The advantage of using ddt is that we only need to write one test for all the input combinations, so we might as well give it a full workout.  The other thing is that I want to be able to assert that the selection function will *never* return None, so I kind of went overboard in considering non-actual input sets ... but now I am confident that the selection function will never return None.

these tests work without the mocking as well (as the types don't exist anyway)
maybe we can remove this in a followup patch

I usually dislike unneeded mocking, but it's a contingent matter of fact that the fake type names don't map to anything, and these mocks remove the contingency so that you'll get an exception whether the type exists or not, which is the behavior we want for this test.  So I think using the mocks keeps this unit test isolated.  But I could very well just be being stubborn here.

cinder/volume/flows/api/create_volume.py.message: nit: IMO,  'identifier = None' will be more clear
I thought I was making a big improvement by not using a defaultdict, but you are right, None would be even better!

instead of this, we can use [1] which will return default_volume_type (if CONF.default_volume_type is set) else it will return __DEFAULT__ type

after this change, i think the changes below aren't required as well

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/volume_types.py#L175

By not having an else here, I can do a fallback at line 384 if it turns out that the value passed in isn't a legitimate volume_type.  This preserves the prior behavior of logging a message and allowing the volume to be built with no volume type, except now we allow the volume to be built with the __DEFAULT__ type.

I disagree.  That won't help in the situation where there's a image_volume_type_id on the image, but it contains a typo or something.  The old behavior was that the volume build would continue but with no volume type; the new behavior should be to continue the build but with the __DEFAULT__ volume type.  Otherwise, we are changing the API behavior too much IMO.  So I think we definitely want the fallback at line 384, and since we have that there, I think it's simpler to just grab the CONF value directly here instead of using the function.
I don't understand the image_volume_type_id relation here but the current behavior now is if the default_volume_type value is set wrong in the CONF file then we raise an exception.

The point is that raising an exception is a big change in behavior and if that's what we wanted to do, it should have been mentioned in the spec.  Until Train, it would have resulted in the volume-create succeeding but with no volume_type.  So a lot of volume-create requests that previously would have succeded now fail.  I think we need to discuss what the expected behavior should be here.

if we set wrong value/name in CONF.default_volume_type then this will assign the default volume type to the volume instead of error out on the wrong name/value set in conf file which is incorrect behavior

The change mentioned results in an exception (see L#186) if the CONF.default_volume_type value is wrong (volume type doesn't exist).
If the user has set a wrong volume type value in conf and we still continue to create a volume with default type seems pretty wrong as they need to know they've set the wrong type and should correct it.

That behavior was introduced by I4da0c13b5b3f8174a30b8557f968d6b9e641b091 and I don't see anything on the spec about that.  The pre-default-volume-type behavior was to log a message and continue, which would result in volume creation (but with an empty volume_type).  It's not obvious to me why we shouldn't continue with volume creation, using the __DEFAULT__ type, which would be basically equivalent to the old behavior.

The function logic itself looks good, but not sure if all the callers have well deal with this change or not.

Does it need to change to below format?
.get('volume_type_id')
I think we're OK because these should be our oslo versioned objects, which can handle this.  (Besides, the old code was using this syntax.)

just a reminder, maybe not worth to do change.

The commit msg in the patch (https://review.opendev.org/525237) gives no hints whatsoever, but in the review comments trown says:

    I think this actually solves the use case we need it for. 
    We only need the set_facts from one playbook run to 
    persist at the same precedence in another playbook run. 
    This change accomplishes that.

    We are currently working on a sprint to allow running 
    individual playbooks from the CI code so as to use it to 
    setup development environments. If we overcomplicate this 
    by creating custom facts modules that will almost 
    certainly mean we do not accomplish that goal this sprint.

    If there is some serious downside to what we are doing, 
    obviously that is worth delaying for. However, I am not 
    seeing that.

So yea, there is a downside!
